More people watched the prime-time network television coverage of Senator Joseph I. Lieberman's address to the Democratic National Convention on Wednesday night than watched a similar vice-presidential address by the Republicans' nominee two weeks ago.

ABC, NBC and CBS were watched by a combined audience estimated at 15 million people in the Democratic convention's third night, shown from 10 p.m. to 11 p.m. E.D.T. The speech by the Republican nominee, Dick
Cheney, on the third night of his convention, was watched by an estimated 14.1 million network viewers, according to Nielsen Media Research data.
But Wednesday night's network audience was smaller than the 16.5 million who watched Al Gore accept the nomination for vice president at the 1996 Democratic convention.
The audiences for public television and cable were also larger on Night 3 of the Democratic convention than they were on that night of the Republican gathering.
The coverage of Mr. Cheney's speech by PBS was watched by an estimated 2.5 million people. About 2.9 million people watched its coverage of Mr. Lieberman's address.

Likewise, 2.1 million people were estimated to have watched Night 3 of the Republican convention on the Fox News Channel, CNN and MSNBC. Nearly 2.3 million watched Night 3 of the Democratic convention on those networks on Wednesday.
CNN's prime-time audience on Wednesday was about 85 percent of what it was on the third night of the 1996 Democratic convention.
